2 years later lol, but I'll just answer for anyone else in the future: you can't say Ek initial of the bullet = Ep of the bullet-block system because its an inelastic collision. In any hit + stick collision, you don't conserve mechanical energy (E kinetic + E potential)  I thought that would work as well, but the thing is, when we talk about inelastic collisions, we're referring to the conservation of MECHANICAL energy (Ep / Ek), not just kinetic energy.  If you did the math, the E kinetic of the bullet does not = the E potential of the whole system. That means energy was lost somewhere. In this case, probably in the form of heat.  The conservation of momentum always works tho (in an isolated system).

Because the bullet is stuck inside the block hence the system is combined.

You can solve this scenario by solving the problem backwards. Start by focusing on just the bullet+block just after the collision takes place. We know that initially, the potential energy of the bullet+block = 0 since it hasn't gained any height yet. We also know that the final kinetic energy of the system once it reaches the maximum height is also 0 since the bullet+block once again isn't moving. So based on the total mechanical energy theorem, we can say for the bullet+block that 0.5mv^2 = mgh where m is the combined mass of the bullet+block, h is the final height of the block, and v is the initial velocity of the bullet+block just after the collision takes place. This can be simplified to v = sqrt(2gh). Once you solve for v, then you can go back to focusing on the collision, and call the value for v you found the  "final" velocity of the bullet+block since it represents the velocity just after the collision happens. Now, this is a momentum problem, since we know that momentum is always conserved for collisions. Thus, to find the initial velocity of the bullet, we can say (m1+m2)vf = m1v1o + m2v2o where m1 is the mass of the bullet, m2 is the mass of the block, vf is the value you found in the first part of the problem which represents the velocity of the bullet and block combined just after the bullet hits,  v1o is the initial velocity of the bullet (which is what you're looking for), and v2o is the initial velocity of the block. Since we know the initial velocity of the block alone is 0, we can simply ignore this term. So the equation becomes: (m1+m2)vf = m1v1o. To solve for v1o, plug in all your numbers, and the number you get represents the initial velocity of the bullet.
